fundamental Insight behind personalization you know seems reasonably obvious is that the evolution

in the future um so uh this is you know reasonably obvious and people have been
trying different ways of capturing these application data specific patterns using
different kinds of machine learning models what I mean by application data specific here is that the actual
patterns depend on a particular application how the website is designed how customers tend to interact with your
service and so on the Insight that's kind of slightly more new is that the
order and timing of these interactions matters a lot more than we thought it used to so what that means is if there's
a large gap between two interactions uh it matter then maybe that interaction is less relevant
anymore and you know to kind of uh show this pictorially we can think about a
customer who's you know looked at three watches and then you know after some delay looked at a shoe then you know
it's reasonable to now recommend shoes to them maybe less reasonable to go back and recommend watches but if the pattern
reversed that is you know first they looked at a shoe and then watches maybe now you want to recommend shoes so how
do you do this in machine learning so the typical approach is you take the historical interactions which is the stuff on the left um and then you
featuri this in some way so maybe you look at features of color size shape category and so on and then you pass it
through a machine learning model which tries to predict the next item right the next item is in this case a watch so uh
the the thing is then now you want to figure out how do you capture the time so you try to encode time in different
ways you say you know an interaction more than one hour ago is less useful so
this kind of feature engineering becomes harder and harder the more variety that you have in your catalog and data sets
uh so this is where things like deep learning are much more useful uh so what uh the kind of the first kind of models
that you would want to try on such data sets are what are called recurrent neural networks so recurrent neural
networks basically give you a good way of learning features that represent items well and learning how the order
matters so given a reasonably large data set of a sequence of interactions they
get better and better at predict at first what uh building what I would call a user representation that is encoding
this entire history well and this user representation can be used to predict
what the customer will uh purchase next typically you know coding such models training them scaling them is reasonably
hard so this is like one of the first models that we include out of the box in
Amazon personalized as a recurrent recommend but uh just capturing sequence
information is not quite enough uh there's this concept which I call sessions but is slightly more generic
than that and the idea being that customer U interests and behavior have
uh evolution over time so you know maybe you are interested in watches for a while until you buy the watch and then
you start getting interested in shoes and you want to buy the shoe right so if you so you want to be able to capture
this so the network has to both learn to remember stuff and learn to forget certain interests once the purchase or
interaction is done right uh so the way we we do this uh is something called a
hierarchical recurrent neural network and the basic idea is that there is a recurrent neural network for every
session or every day every week month or other time period And there's another
recurrent neural network which mod models this evolution of interests and this again you know is reasonably hard
to implement in scale which is why it's again presented out of the box in Amazon personalized so uh uh personalization
and recommendation are well studied tasks people have been trying these things for a while um so what's
interesting is that adding this concept of hierarchies actually gives you a lift on these kind of public data sets uh
which people have had papers on over many many years um and you it turns out
that these same models are useful on a variety of data sets both public and private and for a variety of tasks so
this particular task is rating prediction which is you know you have a sequence of ratings people give movies
and you want to predict what's the rating they'll give to a new movie but what we often care about is will they
buy something next or how good is this recommendation and it turns out that these models are good at also all of
these other tasks as well and we have a paper about it presenting next week but the basic idea is that the single idea
of hierarchies and time allows you to get stateof the art performance on a variety of data
sets um but at the same time once you have so many models so we have a bunch of other models out of the box again in
Amazon personalized we have something called Sims which if you know what it means is a item to item recommendation

a parameter of time Decay so you know at some point I should forget that you uh like maybe if you've not come back to
the site for a year I should not recommend the last thing that you looked at so this has parameters like time
Decay if you have deep factorization models they have parameters like depth and size uh hierarchical networks now
have a new parameter which is height so setting all these parameters on a data set is very hard timec consuming and so
on and as Bindu mentioned uh we do a lot of HBO and automl out of the box so that
you don't have to tune these parameters on your new data set but you still get the best algorithm out of these uh with

Amazon personalized the first one is that these hierarchical sequential models tend to do well on a variety of
data sets for a variety of tasks and we provide stable solutions for these out of the box which already include many of
the tra from Deep learning practitioners um and second we have the automl and HBO
which tune these models on your data so that you get the best possible performance and finally I want to
